title: Finding the perfect loaf of bread at the Sydney Royal Fine Food Show - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Flavour What's in that sourdough? 
Mr Haden's favourite category is the sourdough breads â€” a traditional style made completely from scratch using a base of flour and water fermented with natural bacteria from the air. 
"What sourdough gives you is an incredible moist flavoursome interior to the bread, with quite a large porous texture with lots of 'holes' in the bread," he said. 
"There's a lot of stretchiness and elasticity to the centre of the dough without being chewy. 
"We look for the bloom on the crust which is that varnished look, which can be extraordinary in some places." Bread making tips for first-timers Don't do it unless you're really inspired to make a good loaf, Mr Haden advises. Get 200g of good quality flour or organic flour. Add same quantity of water. Put the mixture on the bench and leave it for 24 hours. Bubbles should form. Build it up with more flour and water to create the dough. Repeat this process. Retain some of the culture and "keep feeding it" to use next time. Keep the yeast starter in the fridge. 
It can take up to three days to build up the initial sourdough starter and several hours to shape then bake the dough. 
Mr Haden said judges found one baker this year had added vinegar into their bread to achieve the "sour taste" recognisable in sourdough loaves. 
"The aroma gave it away," he said. 
"There are bakers out there who cut corners with making that style of bread. 
"If you want to speed [up the process] you add in a bit of commercial yeast ... and then to compensate for not having that longer development, which gives you that authentic taste, you add some vinegar to make it taste like sourdough." 
The winner of each class and overall champion bread will be announced on February 14. 
The Sydney Royal has competitions for a number of other food types including coffee, olive oil, chocolate, pasta, beer and cider and aquaculture.
